summary: As Adm. James T. Kirk (William Shatner) and Capt. It unquestionably has the best space battle ever done, relying on tactics and a real building sense of drama  rather than the CGI and an infinite supply of enemy drones to be destroyed. Yes he is over-acting, but he pulls it off, and the director actually manages to rein in Shatner's overacting into the best performance in the series.  Also one of the best death scenes ever put to film.  Yes, they ruin it by brining the character back in the next episode, but when the film came out there was not a dry eye on the house.  Also Kobayashi Maru, which was so classic that just that opening scene became iconic for all of film culture.

(Spoilers) Terrific sequel to the dull "Star Trek: The Motion Picture".  As Roger Ebert put it on Siskel and Ebert back in 82, "All Star Trek needed was a good Darth Vader."  And boy does Montalban deliver!  With his sexy, barrel-chested warlord barbarian; seething with viciousness and superiority; and more importantly; with an established history with Kirk and the Enterprise crew which he tried to mutiny decades before; Khan may be one of filmdom's best villains. He does in fact give Vader a run for the money!  It's too bad they had to kill him off- he would have made a great recurring villain.  The Enterprise crew is much more fleshed out this time around; allowing the humanity, humor and chemistry that made the original show so special. Only complaint: it was a mistake to have Kirk and Khan's entire conflict play out as they scream at eachother through teleprompters.  They should have met at some point and battled hand to hand; the story would have been much stronger. Supposedly there was originally going to be a scene like that but it was cut out-and that was a big mistake.  Still, the movie's still awesome; still highly recommended!

For this uninitiated casual fan, it's an ambivalent experience watching this in 2022 for the first time on a massive screen. How did a film with such dated/dodgy special effects (which wasn't that wonderful even back in 1982) and a fair amount of overacting from its central cast, manage to attract such adoration from people who would scoff otherwise, while making grown men (and women) weep? After its lacklustre first attempt to move from the small to the big screen, this sequel boldly takes inspiration from s1e22 of the TV show as its starting point. After being exiled to an uninhabitable planet with his motley crew of New Romantics rejects many years ago, a chance happening allows Ricardo Montalban's Khan to escape and exact revenge on Captain Kirk and the SS Enterprise. With Nicholas Meyer's proficient directing, acting levels that vary from pseudo-Shakespearean to shouting to William Shatner, and a screenplay introducing Bibi Besch and Marritt Butrick's mother-and-son scientists-in-peril, this space soap opera is ready to go where many (writers) have been before. The film is, to borrow Spock's famous assessment, illogical, yet no matter how naff or silly it is, its warm fuzzy nostalgic charm simply cannot be denied, and perhaps here lies the key to the appreciation of this film. Behind the scene politics might have accidentally bestowed a poignant ending here that commercial considerations later will unravel, but it's one of its few true emotional moments that explains why this franchise still maintains such a fiercely loyal following four decades later. I may find this dated and I've still got more questions than answers about its dubious plotting but, fans or not, one can't really begrudge a film that gifted us that wonderfully camp yet ridiculously endearing Khhhhhaannnn!! meme, which perfectly sums up the film for me.

'Star Trek: The Motion Picture', to me, is a better film than its reputation but was also a disappointment and could have been much better. Every film franchise has to start somewhere, and 'The Motion Picture' paved the way to better films. Of which the second film 'The Wrath of Khan' is among the best, a strong contender for the best. Much appreciated its darker tone, emotional wallop and that it was much better paced and action-oriented than 'The Motion Picture'.

It may not be as visually stunning as 'The Motion Picture' (the production values is one of only two areas that is done better in that film to here), and William Shatner still goes overboard in his acting. Then again Shatner was never known for subtlety and when he was restrained (like 1958's 'The Brothers Karamazov') those instances were rare.

'The Wrath of Khan' is hardly cheap-looking though, having better production values generally than the original series. The sets are more elaborate, the photography is moody and stylish and the special effects are hardly hokey. While Jerry Goldsmith's music is missed a little, James Horner is more than up to the plate, not as rousing but typically beautifully orchestrated and high in the thrills factor. The sound effects are suitably eerie.

Writing is an improvement, getting to the point more and less talk heavy, it is very intelligent and thought-provoking without being overly serious. The story has no pacing issues, being much tighter and with much more going on. Credit is due too for exploring (beautifully) dark and universal themes. Nicholas Meyer is a more than welcome replacement, showing more of a sense of loyalty to the original series while bringing his own style without being too ambitious.

Acting, with the exception of Shatner, is good. Leonard Nimoy has rarely been more moving, with a truly powerful final scene, and Riccardo Montalban rarely so deliciously campy (without ever hurting the film's tone and still being entertaining) and also menacing. No pointless or underwritten characters here.

Star Trek The Wrath of Khan is definitely episodic, but has more action and more special effects than the first Star Trek film, which will delight all types of Sci-Fi fans. It was inspired choice to bring back one of the most popular characters from the original Star Trek TV series, Ricardo Montalbán as Khan Noonien Singh, the genetically enhanced, megalomaniac super-soldier left over from Earth's Eugenics wars, and an excellent adversary for the courageous, good-willed Captain Kirk. However, Kirstie Alley, one of the most emotional actresses in the industry, is totally miscast as the emotionally controlled Vulcan, Saavik. The script cleverly acknowledges the fear many members of the principal cast were feeling about their ageing process being revealed to all on the big screen, with Shatner's character Kirk expressing his regret about celebrating yet another birthday. However, the introduction of what is revealed to be Kirk's now fully grown adult son feels forced, something that is convenient for the script, but not consistent with Star Trek canon. Kirk pays little regard to David from that point on, making it difficult to believe he is so devastated at David's loss in the next sequel. The pace of this film is much better than the first Star Trek picture, showing that the filmmakers realised their mistakes in the first film. The action sequences are exciting, and the decision to hold the final battle scenes inside a nebula was also inspired, invoking memories of another great Star Trek TOS episode, Balance of Terror. The special effects are also much better, the film being noteworthy for having the first fully CGI sequence used in a motion picture. Nimoy's death scene done well, and was quite shocking to Star Trek fans in the day. However, it would having been moving if they had been generous with the make-up effects, underscoring how much he had suffered with his sacrifice to save the ship. Instead, the moment of his death is a bit underwhelming. Shatner, on the other hand, seems genuinely distressed about the loss of his friend, perhaps more so than in the next movie when he is informed that his son David had been killed. Of course, Shatner may have just been genuinely upset at realising Nimoy had just stolen the show. Star Trek The Wrath of Khan is fun and exciting sci-fi, in keeping with Star Trek tradition. This was the right film to follow up Star Trek The Motion Picture, and deservedly one of the fan favourites.

We're approaching 40 years since this movie came out and since seeing it at the cinemas as an 8 year old it's not only one I return to regularly, it seems to get better with age.  The tone is pitch-perfect, with superb direction getting great performances from a group of talented former TV actors.  The low budget (only $12m) forces all involved to make the situations as tense as possible rather than relying on showy space battles.  It's themes of ageing, death and the cycle of life are a solid platform for the fun and adventure throughout.

James Horner's score is fantastic, driving along a tight, at times humorous, emotional and knowing script that keeps the sci-fi grounded in a believable world (the opening title card 'In The 23rd Century...' is the perfect counterbalance to Star Wars 'A Long Time Ago').  Made for only $12m, it still remains the best Star Trek film ever made.  Truly lightning in a bottle.

YES! Now THAT is a Star Trek film. I was worried that 25 year-old rose tinted specs would mean I was disappointed by this one - no way. Fast, fun, and full of action. I’d forgotten just how awesome Ricardo Montalban is as Khan, and how great Khan is as Kirk’s nemesis. The film builds to the incredible crescendo of the blind battle inside the nebula where Kirk finally gets the upper hand and cripples the Reliant, causing Khan to try to wipe the Enterprise out with the Genesis device. Spock’s sacrifice is brought to us brilliantly; it’s not overly dramatic, but the poignancy of the act comes across perfectly. 4.5/5, only failing to achieve full bananas due to a slightly weaker musical score and the obvious re-use of a couple of scenes from the first film. Amazingly, the deeply mediocre Star Trek: The Motion Picture not only did not kill the franchise but was financially just successful enough to prompt the creation of a second Star Trek film. That film was Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan, and it is a vast improvement over its predecessor. The film was directed by Nicholas Meyer, who reportedly had never seen the television series prior to being hired to direct but compensated for this lack of familiarity by binge watching the entire series. Meyer noticed that the episode "Space Seed" had an interesting villain and the potential for continuation. Hence, The Wrath of Khan is a sequel to "Space Seed", depicting the escape of that episode's genetically engineered superman Khan from the planet to which he and his followers were exiled.

Nicholas Meyer was correct in concluding that Khan could be made into an interesting villain. Khan is fascinating, intelligent and threatening but flawed in his overconfidence and his obsession with revenge against Kirk. His motivations, unlike some other Star Trek villains, are also understandable – he has lost his wife and many of his friends and blames Kirk for placing him in the situation which, however inadvertently, caused this to happen. Regarding his obsession with revenge, his character takes some inspiration from Captain Ahab, down to directly quoting Moby Dick and the appearance of a copy of the novel as a background prop in one of the opening scenes, although not to the point of being a clone. He is played by the same actor as in The Original Series, Ricardo Montalbán, who gives a fine performance.

This being Star Trek, Khan's revenge naturally involves a few space battles. The opening fight between the Enterprise and the Reliant is one of my favorite battle scenes in all of science fiction. This is not because of exceptional effects or scale. Rather, I love this scene because of the tension it builds through a combination of dramatic irony and rapid cross cutting, and because of the significance it has in establishing the characters – the Enterprise survives because of Kirk's quick-thinking and Khan's overconfidence and need to gloat at his adversary.

This scene and the rest of the scenes in the movie are accompanied by a fantastic score by Academy Award winning composer James Horner. As much as I love Ron Jones' work for Star Trek: The Next Generation, the score to The Wrath of Khan is superior work. Indeed, this is the score which plays in my head whenever I think of Star Trek. Speaking of iconic additions to the Trek universe, the Starfleet uniforms created for The Wrath of Khan were used for the rest of the Original Series movies, and for good reason – they are undoubtedly my favorite Trek uniforms and vastly superior to the pajama-like uniforms from The Motion Picture.

Some fans believe The Wrath of Khan saved the franchise. Regardless of whether this is true or not, Star Trek would certainly be less without it. The Wrath of Khan is one of the high points of the franchise – while it ditches some of The Motion Picture's flashy effects, it is hard to care when the script is far better written and includes concrete themes such as revenge and dealing with aging and death. Despite having the lowest budget out of all the official Star Trek films, The Wrath of Khan is easily my favorite. It proves, as the Original Series proved years earlier, that a low budget film or television show can become a classic if it has talented and passionate people on board

My only complaint about Wrath of Khan comes in the slow build of the first act. In the year 2285, the USS Reliant is on a mission to search for a lifeless planet for testing of the Genesis Device, a technology designed to reorganize matter to create habitable worlds for colonization. Reliant officers Commander Pavel Chekov (Walter Koenig) and Captain Clark Terrell beam down to the surface of a possible candidate planet, which they believe to be Ceti Alpha VI; once there, they are captured by genetically engineered tyrant Khan Noonien Singh (Ricardo Montalban). 15 years prior, the Enterprise discovered Khan's ship adrift in space; Admiral James T. Kirk (William Shatner) exiled Khan and his fellow supermen to Ceti Alpha V after they attempted to take over the Enterprise. After they were marooned, Ceti Alpha VI exploded, shifting the orbit of Ceti Alpha V and destroying its ecosystem. Khan blames Kirk for the death of his wife and plans revenge. He implants Chekov and Terrell with indigenous creatures that enter the ears of their victims and render them susceptible to mind control, and uses the officers to capture the Reliant. Learning of Genesis, Khan attacks space station Regula I where the device is being developed by Kirk's former lover, Dr. Carol Marcus, and their son, David. Next up is the utter destruction of Kirk...

After the lukewarm reaction to the first film, fan response to The Wrath of Khan was highly positive. The Wrath of Khan was released in North America on June 4, 1982. It was a box office success, earning US$97 million worldwide and setting a world record for first-day box office gross. The film's success was credited with renewing interest in the franchise. Mark Bernardin of Entertainment Weekly went further, calling The Wrath of Khan "the film that, by most accounts, saved Star Trek as we know it"; it is now considered one of the best films in the series. The film's pacing was praised by reviewers in The New York Times and The Washington Post as being much swifter than its predecessor and closer to that of the television series. Janet Maslin of The New York Times credited the film with a stronger story than The Motion Picture and stated the sequel was everything the first film should have been. Variety agreed that The Wrath of Khan was closer to the original spirit of Star Trek than its predecessor. Strong character interaction was cited as a strong feature of the film, as was Montalbán's portrayal of Khan. Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times and Derek Adams of Time Out complained about what were seen as tepid battle sequences, and perceived melodrama. While Ebert and TV Guide felt that Spock's death was dramatic and well-handled, The Washington Post's Gary Arnold stated Spock's death "feels like an unnecessary twist, and the filmmakers are obviously well-prepared to fudge in case the public demands another sequel". Negative reviews of the film also focused on the acting, and Empire singled out the "dodgy coiffures" and "Santa Claus tunics" as elements of the film that had not aged well.

After the lackluster critical and commercial response to The Motion Picture, series creator Gene Roddenberry was forced out of the sequel's production. Executive producer Harve Bennett wrote the film's original outline, which Jack B. Sowards developed into a full script. Director Nicholas Meyer completed the final script in 12 days, without accepting a writing credit. Meyer's approach evoked the swashbuckling atmosphere of the original series, and the theme was reinforced by James Horner's musical score. Nimoy had not intended to have a role in The Motion Picture's sequel, but was enticed back on the promise that his character would be given a dramatic death scene. Negative test audience reaction to Spock's death led to significant revisions of the ending over Meyer's objections. The production used various cost-cutting techniques to keep within budget, including utilizing miniatures from past projects and re-using sets, effects footage and costumes from the previous movie. Among the film's technical achievements is it being the first feature film to contain a complete sequence created entirely with computer-generated graphics.

Sequels are supposed to take what was great about the first outing and expand on it while also improving upon the mishaps as well.  Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan is better than the first film in almost every aspect.  I took issue with the pacing, overuse of special effects, length, and the lack of a present villain in Star Trek: The Motion Picture.  This film wipes away silly and unnecessary special effects and gives us an intriguing story with characters who we understand and care about.  It's also a solid 30 minutes shorter without cutting out anything that would hurt the story.  I was thoroughly impressed by this sequel even 30 years after its release.

We open the film as the enterprise seemingly has a new captain in Kirstie Alley's Saavik, only to find out its a training exercise put together by Spock and Admiral Kirk.  I was worried they may rehash the same story line as the first film as Kirk seemed to hint that he may be done with the Enterprise, only to run into an old foe in Khan.  Even though I have seen bits and pieces of the original series and had been somewhat familiar with Khan as a villain, I didn't know to the extent to which him and Kirk were linked.  I was glad to see viewing of his appearance in the TV series wasn't entirely necessary as they explained enough in the 103 minute run-time.

Khan has become somewhat of a pop culture icon over the years, so I had my fair share of expectations going in.  Ricardo Montalban's performance and the writing didn't let me down.  So much so that you understand where Khan is coming from when he wants Project Genesis from the crew and wants revenge for what Kirk did.  In many ways, he was Kirk's arch nemesis and proved to come through with a lot of what he swore to do to Kirk.  My only gripe with him as a villain was that I feel like we were missing an in person interaction with Kirk himself.  Speaking through a video screen inside the Enterprise isn't enough, you need that human interaction.

With that said, The Wrath of Khan has the emotional layers and character depths that the first film was lacking.  All of the original dynamics of the ship are there, plus some new and enjoyable ones as well.  Plus, it doesn't take 45 minutes for things to get going, the pacing is much improved.  James Horner's haunting score also sets the tone immediately from the opening scene, all the way through the bittersweet ending.  Overall, everything feels bigger and better with The Wrath of Khan.  Having seen the new Trek films, I think this can rank up there with them as some of the best outings the Enterprise crew has ever had.

Movie Prep:

This film is pretty much the big budget sequel to 'Space Seed', an episode from the original television show. So watching that show before you see Khan is recommended, but not critical as The Wrath of Khan fills in enough of the back story as to not be too confusing. It's worth a watch even if you're not really into Star Trek, as its themes of revenge, destiny and aging are universal so who cares if all that is played out in space, with the occasional really cool space battle?

Best Format:

The special effects still hold up well. Especially the final dog fight in the cloud nebula. If your local theater was revisiting this film, certainly try to get a ticket for that. At home a HD showing is recommended. James Horner's superb score requires a decent sound system to be properly appreciated.

Best elements for me:

So many to choose from. Ricardo Montalban's super slick performance. The battle in the nebula is always entertaining to watch, and the scene between Spock and Kirk at the end of the film always brings a tear to my eye (what! I'm not ashamed to admit it!) It's just all so good!

After The Motion Picture was a critical disappointment, many were wondering if there will be a Trek film that stays true to the spirit of the TV show. Enter Nicholas Meyer, a little-known director at the time who had never watched a Trek episode in his life. Taking information out of a Trek episode titled "Space Seed", which was about a famous villain named Khan, Meyer decided to make a Trek sequel involving Khan and a revenge scheme. And the result paid off; not only was The Wrath of Khan a bigger critical hit than The Motion Picture, to this day, it's still regarded as one of the best Trek films and was one of the inspirations to the plot of Star Trek Into Darkness. As for me, The Wrath of Khan is an excellent Trek film that shows to me that the older Trek films are truly worth watching.

Admiral Kirk (William Shatner) escapes a normal desk job to return with Spock (Leonard Nimoy), Dr. Bones (DeForest Kelley), and Scotty (James Doohan) on another voyage on the Enterprise. But on this journey, he reunites with an old enemy; Khan (Ricardo Montalban), a war criminal that Kirk had formally exiled, who's dying for revenge. Khan leads other prisoners, assumes command of a Starfleet ship, and goes after the Genesis Project, a project intending to give life to dying planets, for his own purposes as part of his scheme to ruin Kirk once and for all.

This film also features George Takei as Sulu, Walter Koenig as Checkov, Nichelle Nichols as Uhura, Bibi Besch as Kirk's wife Carol, Merrit Butrick as Kirk's son David, and in her film debut, Kirstie Alley as Vulcan Saavick.

One of the common complaints with The Motion Picture was the lack of character development, which was something that I complained about. With The Wrath of Khan, things have changed to where there is much better characterization by making the common audience (non-Trekkies) actually care about these characters. It's not perfect, as some are still completely underdeveloped, especially Uhura and Sulu, but as a whole, character development has definitely improved. The acting has improved as well, Nichelle Nichols and George Takei, while their characters are still completely underdeveloped, had much better acting this time around than their roles in The Motion Picture. Bibi Besch and Merritt Butrick are good as Kirk's family members, especially Butrick. Kirstie Alley, who I expected to be a heavy miscast due to being most famous in TV comedies, is surprisingly enjoyable as the female Vulcan Saavick. It's cool to see a fellow Vulcan other than Spock once in a while. James Doohan has improved a lot as Scotty to where he's likable and far more entertaining to hang around with. DeForest Kelley is great again as Dr. Bones, continuing his common humor and entertainment levels. Leonard Nimoy is excellent here as Spock, with great characterization and is even extremely moving in the last third of the film. The biggest improvement acting wise for sure is William Shatner as Kirk. I liked him in The Motion Picture, but I just couldn't really care too much about him. In The Wrath of Khan, his characterization has improved the most to where I actually care about what happens to his character. Shatner, an actor who I once thought as extremely cheesy, actually gives a wonderful performance playing his most famous role. If he continues to be this great in the rest of the franchise, then I'll be more excited to root for Shatner.

But there's one thing missing about the film acting wise, and that's Khan, who's played by Ricardo Montalban. Since I did not watch the original series, I had no knowledge of the episode that introduced Khan. But the good news is that for those who've never watched the show the movie is so good and so easy to understand that watching the Trek episode with Khan isn't really necessary, maybe for die-hard Trekkies though. Montalban nails the role of Khan, with as much evil in the role as Cumberbatch perfects in Into Darkness. With experiencing this and Into Darkness, I have no doubt that Khan is likely the best villain in the Trek films.

I also was impressed that the story was much darker this time around, especially for a Trek film with The Original Series cast. The film plays well the strategies of Kirk and Khan's plans to defeat each other. The visuals, which were created by Industrial Light and Magic, are a improve over The Motion Picture, with the model ships looking more realistic than ever before. And the score by James Horner is a delightful listen to. 

It's not a perfect film; there's still come characters that need to have full development (I'm looking at you, Uhura, Checkov, and Sulu!), but in the end, The Wrath of Khan is an excellent sequel that proves that the older films are as strong as the newer films. The main characters are better developed, the acting is great, the villain is excellent, the tension is heated up to a darker level, the visuals are outstanding, and the ending is another moving and thought-provoking ending in the Trek franchise. With The Wrath of Khan, I'm more excited about seeing how the rest of the franchise will turn out.

As I've said before, I am not a big Star Trek fan. I'm even less of a fan when it came to the movies that eventually spawned out of it. That being said, there is one film that not only stands above the rest, but remains arguably one of the most thoughtful and surprising sequels ever made. It is the film even none Star Trek fans like: The Wrath of Khan. 

In the 1960's Star Trek was unceremoniously cancelled by NBC due to low rating after its 3rd season. But over time, the already dedicated fanbase grew even larger, resulting in the release of a a feature film: Star Trek The Motion picture. And it unfortunately wasn't Wrath of Khan. It was slow, boring, and was a disappointment to the fans. But somehow, the writers and directors got their act together and made the movie that would epitomize Star Trek's legacy and insure its survival as a series of feature films. 

The story follows Kirk (William Shatner), now in his later years, has been promoted to Admiral. But he feels his best days are behind him, and he longs for the adventures he had in his youth. Still all things are pretty good, until his old enemy Khan, played by Ricardo Montalban, returns. In the original series he was a genetically advanced but brilliant conqueror from Earth's past. Kirk left him and his crew stranded on a deserted planet with no hope of escape. But escape he did, and he's back for revenge and armed with a deadly new weapon known as the genesis device. Now Kirk has to command the Enterprise once again and assemble his crew. 

This is by far one of the best and most entertaining story we've gotten from Star Trek. Gone are some of the campy moments (for the most part) and instead we get one hell of an entertaining chess match between two iconic characters. You can tell that the actors have gotten much more comfortable in their roles as they have aged. Even Shatner, the king of hammy acting, gives a restrained and excellent performance (with the exception of the infamous KHANNNNNN line). The show down between Khan and Kirk is awesome to see onscreen. Even though they never have a scene with the two of them face to face, you know immediately that they are archenemies. There is a reason Khan remains the best villain in all of Star Trek. 

SPOILERS FROM HERE ON OUT

But by far the best aspect of the film is the famous death of Spock. Everyone, even none Trek fans, knows and respects Spock. He is the most iconic character. This film made the gutsy move to kill him off in a great heroic sacrifice. He dies sacrificing his life to save the Enterprise. This is the most iconic and one the best scenes in the series's history. The reason this works, besides the writing and acting, is because you legitimately believe in the weight and certainty of the death. It deconstructs Kirk's "no loose situation" personal by showing that sometimes there are no win scenarios. I know Spock does come back in sequels, but personally I don't care. This was the end of his character and it was a damn good finale. 

This is a great movie. There are only a few goofy moments and convenient plot points that keep it from being perfect. The special effects are dated, but that really shouldn't matter. In a few decades, films like Avatar and Transformers will seem dated. Its the story and characters that matter.

As a dedicated fan of the original series, as well as the franchise in general, I must say that I was awed at The Wrath of Khan. Rarely ever have films (or any media in general) been successful when using a prior plot point. An example is the episode "The Naked Now", the third episode of the first season of Star Trek: The Next Generation. This episode pulled a plot out of the episode "The Naked Time" from the Original Series, and turned out very unoriginal and very unsatisfying.

However, The Wrath of Khan pulls a plot point from the Original Series television episode, "Space Seed", in which the crew of the Enterprise first encounters Khan Noonien Singh, a dictator from Earth's past who has been in suspended animation for over two and a half centuries. He then tries to hijack the Enterprise, but is stopped by then-Captain Kirk. Kirk then exiles Khan and his people to the hospitable planet of Ceti Alpha V, where Khan has the chance to build a new life for him and his crew.

The Wrath of Khan picks up fifteen years later, when Chekov (now with the USS Reliant) and Captain Terrell beam down onto the surface of Ceti Alpha V, which they mistake for Ceti Alpha VI. Their purpose; to  check Ceti Alpha VI for signs of preanimate life before testing of the Genesis Device, a torpedo-like mechanism which can be used to terraform dead planets. They discover a cargo hold, inside of which Chekov finds the insignia of the SS Botany Bay, the ship Khan was on when the Enterprise found him. Realizing what Captain Terrell and he have stumbled upon, Chekov tells the Captain that they need to leave immediately. Once they step outside the cargo hold, they find themselves surrounded by Khan and his people.

Khan then places creatures in the ears of Captain Terrell and Chekov, which Khan uses to control them. Originally intending to seek revenge on Admiral Kirk, he then learns of the Genesis Device, and it's capability to destroy planets. He then uses the two to beam his people and himself aboard the Reliant, which he then takes control of. Once in control, he heads toward Regula 1, the space station where the Genesis Device is being developed. En route, he uses Chekov to inform Regula 1 that the Reliant will be taking hold of the Genesis Device. When the head of the project, Dr. Carol Marcus, asks as to who gave the order, Chekov replies that it was Admiral Kirk.

The Enterprise is on a training mission when Dr. Marcus sends a distress call to Admiral Kirk, aboard the Enterprise. He takes command of the ship, and sets a course for Regula 1. On their way there, Khan ambushes the Enterprise. With most of the trainees killed or injured, Kirk feigns submission. Khan asks for all the information that Kirk has on the Genesis device to be handed over. He gives the Admiral some time to gather the information, during which Kirk uses a prefix code to lower the shields of the Reliant, and attacks. This damages the Reliant, and Khan quickly retreats for the time-being. Kirk then continues to Regula 1, and beams down into the laboratory with Dr. McCoy and newly-added Lieutenant Saavik. There they find the corpses of the Regula 1 team, along with Chekov and Captain Terrell. 

They then realize that Dr. Marcus and her son, David (who is later revealed also to be Admiral Kirk's son), are hiding deep within the planet that Regula 1 is in orbit around, along with the Genesis device. The group then beams down to their position, where it is revealed that Chekov and Captain Terrell were being used by Khan to discover where the Genesis device was. Khan then beams the device aboard the Reliant, and commands the duo to kill Kirk. Though the eel inflicts severe pain on his brain, Captain Terrell resists and shoots himself, while Chekov collapses to the floor. The eel removes itself from Chekov's head. 

Though the duo fails to kill Kirk, Khan assumes that the party is stranded within the planet, overhearing coded message that Spock sends to Kirk, intending to trick Khan into believing so. The party is then beamed back aboard the Enterprise, which Kirk sends into the Mutara Nebula. Within the nebula, both the shields and targeting systems of the Enterprise and Reliant are useless, making the two ships an equal chance. In a very entertaining battle, Kirk disables the Reliant. Khan, on the verge of death, activates the Genesis device, intending to destroy the Enterprise, which is within the blast radius. 

The Enterprise, sensing the activation, tries to move out of the blast radius, but cannot do so with a damaged warp drive. With Kirk preoccupied, Spock moves down to Engineering, with intent to fix the warp drive. When McCoy tries to prevent Spock from doing so (as it would result in the death of Spock), Spock incapacitates McCoy. He then performs a mind-meld on an unconscious McCoy, saying to him "Remember.". Spock then enters the room where he can fix the warp drive, which is flooded with radiation. He successfully fixes the warp drive, but he becomes too weak to leave.

Still unaware of Spock's situation, Kirk then directs the Enterprise out of the blast radius. The Genesis device explodes, and the Enterprise is not harmed. Scotty then tells Kirk to come down to Engineering, where Kirk finds Spock. Spock is at death's door, and is sitting up next to the glass separating the room he is in from the rest of Engineering. Kirk comes up to the other side of the glass, and Spock speaks his dying words. After an emotional moment, Spock dies from radiation poisoning.

At the end of the film, the crew of the Enterprise is gathered around Spock's coffin, where Kirk gives an eulogy. Spock's coffin is then shot out of the Enterprise, and is sent down onto the newly-formed Genesis planet, which was formed when the Genesis device exploded within the Mutara Nebula. 

Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan was a fantastic film. With grade-A battle scenes, an entertaining and original plot, and an ending that would make fans everywhere tear-up, The Wrath of Khan proves to be a classic. A classic that will live forever within the hearts and minds of it's fans, and one that I will most certainly show my children.

The genetically advanced warrior Khan has escaped exile and plans to use the "Genesis" device, which can create life out of nothing, as a weapon. It's up to Kirk, Spock, and the Enterprise crew. 

The film, while having some very good action, also takes it's time to develop the characters and delves into some very poignant themes. The film explores the concept of death and how people often deal with it. The focus is mostly on Kirk, who, when presented with a no win situation, always found a way out. His match with Khan however, forces him to confront the idea that sometimes there is no third option and you will have to deal with your our mortality and the deaths of the people you love. This theme is really at the heart of the film, which makes it a cut above not just Star Trek films, but also most other films in it's genre. There are some slow moments and not everything has aged well for the film over the last thirty years. But even despite these flaws it remains one of the best Star Trek films. 

The last few minutes of the film are some of the best moments of anything I've seen from the series. Even Shatner who usually hams it up (although he does a little in the film), delivers a truly moving performance. Excuse me; I might just have something in my eyes....

Star Trek The Motion Picture didn't set the bar too high, but who could hope that Wrath of Khan will become one of the best sequels of all time. Driven by brilliant perfomance from Ricardo Montalban as Khan and simply, but tense revenge plot Star Trek II is a movie that never loses its original appeal, no matter how many time you saw it.

On Space Station Regula I, the Genesis Device is being developed, a device capable of making planets with hostile environments habitable. Used wrongly, it can also destroy planets. While exploring a planet on which to test the device, Chekhov (Koenig) is captured by Khan (Montalban), a genetically enhanced villain who Kirk (Shatner) had exiled on a remote planet fifteen years earlier, (as seen in the original series episode 'Space Seed'). Khan is obsessed with getting even with Kirk and, having gained control of Chekhov's mind, uses him to lure Kirk to Regula I. When the Enterprise is ambushed by Khan, a battle of wits begins between Kirk and his old nemesis.
Though it was far from a commercial flop, the negative critical and public reaction to 'Star Trek: The Motion Picture' had Paramount worried about the prospects of a sequel. The decision was taken to opt for a more action oriented approach, as opposed to the philosophical feel of the first movie. Gene Roddenberry was removed from the production team in a move which, though cruel, probably needed to be taken. Sometimes it takes a neutral eye to revitalize a franchise and the director hired, Nicholas Meyer, had never even seen an episode of the TV show before landing the job.

Meyer was a fan of C.S Forester's 'Hornblower' series of seafaring novels and borrowed this theme for his script. Essentially, 'Wrath of Khan' is a chess game played between the commanders of two starships; Kirk's Enterprise and Khan's hijacked Reliant. The rivalry between the two is one of the most memorable in science fiction cinema but they never actually meet face to face. Shatner wanted the film to end with a punch-up between the two men but, thankfully, the director ignored him. Meyer's vision of Kirk played up the fact that Shatner was aging and turned the character into a wise old owl, the sort of role Spencer Tracy would have played.
Though Montalban is a formidable presence here, this is well and truly Shatner's movie. He's often mocked, (and he's often the first to mock himself), but what he may lack in technical acting chops, Shatner makes up for in raw charisma. By the film's end, it's a wonder the bridge of the Enterprise is still intact, such is the level of scenery-chewing on display. The famous "Khaaaaaannnnnnnn!!!!!!!!!!" roar has gone down in movie history and is probably Shatner's most famous few seconds of screen time. Of course, the strength of 'Star Trek' lay in the friendship between Kirk, McCoy (Kelley) and Spock (Nimoy), and that relationship is well handled here, with some great barbs traded between the emotional McCoy and the logical Spock.

Meyer's only previous directorial outing was the Jack the Ripper time travel movie 'Time after Time'. His filmography post 'Wrath of Khan' is sparse, a shame as he shows here he really knows how to put a film together. Most of the film takes place on the bridges of two starships but Meyer manages to inject an energy into the whole affair without having to resort to any flashy or distracting tricks. Particularly clever is the montage of lights turning on as the Enterprise leaves it's docking station. Meyer would return to the director's chair for 1991's 'The Undiscovered Country' but that movie aside his CV is pretty barren. Listening to his DVD commentaries gives you the impression of a very opinionated and uncompromising individual and this may be the reason his stock didn't rise in Hollywood. It's a shame as Hollywood could use a film-maker of Meyer's talent.
Though Jerry Goldsmith had written a stunning score for the first film, he was replaced by the young James Horner for the sequel. Horner's score is very different, employing a more nautical theme at Meyer's request, but it's just as good as Goldsmith's.
'Wrath of Khan' is one of those rare films that pleases hardcore fans and mainstream audiences equally. Should you wish to introduce a newcomer to 'Star Trek', this is arguably the best place to start. After seeing this gripping tale, they'll be thirsty for more.

"Admiral James T. Kirk" (William Shatner) and the senior staff from the crew he once commanded are now training the next generation of "Starfleet" officers on his former command, the "USS Enterprise," when they are activated for duty to investigate the mysterious loss of communications of "Regula One," a space laboratory that is working on the secret project codenamed "Genesis." 

On their way to the labortory, they run into the "USS Reliant," which contacts the "Enterprise". However, instead of "Captain Clark Terrell" (Paul Winfield), they are contacted by "Khan Noonien Singh" (Ricardo Montalban, reprising his role from an episode of "Star Trek), who, along with his geneticly-engineered crew from the 1990's spaceship, the "SS Botany Bay", hijacked the starship. The "Enterprise" crew learn that "Khan" wants two things -- the "Genesis Device" and to kill "Kirk," whom he blames for the death of his wife. 

This has to be the best of the "Trek" feature films. It has very few problems with it. 

First of all, the story is well done. It has adventure, and is well written. There are a few points in the original that didn't make it to the scrren that explains a few things in the movie, but they are minor and not really needed. 

The cast is amazing, and possibly gives their best performances since moving to the silver screen. Montalban, who never appears on the same set with other main actors in the movie, is fantastic as one of his most famous television characters who built a passion for vengeance since he first crossed paths with "Kirk" and his crew. 

Another good performance is by Kirstie Alley, in her acting debut. Any actor who can perform without showing emotion has to be good, however she did show slight emotional outbursts in some scenes, as did fellow "Vulcan" actor Leonard Nimoy. Their emotional outburst were warranted in those particular scenes though. 

One problem script is the character development of "Dr. Carol and Dr. David Marcus" (Bibi Beesch and Merritt Butrick). Another development problem is the relationship between "Kirk" and "Dr. Carol Marcus", you learn they had a prior relationship, but the relationship isn't expanded upon in the movie. 

The special effects are as good as other "Trek" movies, and hold up well after all these years. There is one special effect that didn't hold up well, and it is pretty obvious that the actor involved in the FX is in front of a blue screen. The special effects that work best are the space scenes, and are spectacular. 

If you are looking for a good science-fiction movie, then rent this movie.

I have never been a fan of Star Trek.  In the Trek Vs. Wars battle that has raged over Nerdstrom for many moon, I've always been on the Lucas side of things rather than the Roddenberry.
The Wrath of Khan though is one of those films that has left such a mark on sci-fi cinema that it feels like it needs to be watched, even if you're not a fan of the franchise it comes from.  And it is perhaps with good reason, as it's a worthwhile movie that even a non-fan can enjoy.
The Enterprise crew were all already starting to look a little long in the tooth at this stage and as the film opens they've been reduced to training the new recruits at Star Fleet.  On the other side of the galaxy a fellow Star Fleet cruiser intercepts a distress call en route to a top secret scientific space research lab only to be hijacked by the titular Khan and his band of Duran Duran video extras, a man with revenge against a certain James T. Kirk on his mind.
I am assuming that the likes of Shatner and Nimoy play to standard in the film, their performances are enjoyable while the likes of a young Kirstie Alley provide a youthful aspect to the cast.  The stand out in the film is Ricardo Montalban's villain Khan, a performance equally as devilishly evil as his Ludwig in The Naked Gun.  Khan is hell bent and twisted with a desire for revenge which Ricardo plays out very well.  It's easy to see why the character has become a classic in sci-fi bad guy lore.
The action is a little bit on the daft side with some obvious camera titling while folk throw themselves on the floor but the duelling spaceships are all good fun and the threat that Khan poses to the Earth is of a suitably galactic proportion.
The Wrath of Khan might not convert everyone into becoming a Trekkie but it is a very solid film and it's very clear to see why those who have an emotional attachment to the series and characters would hail it as a classic.  Not bad at all.
